text:
I've been doing a lot more work as a "writing coach" recently...trying to build a bench of strong writers vs. focusing on hitting deadlines on my publication calendar :slightly_smiling_face: It's forced me to think about my editing process, and how to break it up into manageable phases for new writers. I jotted down some thoughts here: <https://medium.com/@janessalantz/how-to-coach-new-writers-d5c7612c2fe5>

I find this work to be very challenging -- trying to get the article to a good place while also keeping the writer plugged in and excited about the process. Would love any thoughts from this group.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: As far as advice for new (or longtime) writers, I'm always drawn to Henry Miller's "pretend the page is an ear." (At least concerning a blank page.) I think it helps to show new writers that writing isn't some intimidating, opaque process. It's just communicating, the same way you would communicate with someone verbally. Writing is just getting out of your own way and clearly stating your ideas in an organized manner. The quote helps with writer's block too. Anyway, slightly off-topic but I wanted to share because that quote haunts me, in the best way

text: yeah, that's good :slightly_smiling_face: I've recommended to so many new writers to just record themselves talking about  a topic and then use the transcription as their first draft. No one EVER does it :joy: I think new writers don't quite believe that good writing sounds more like an engaging presentation than a formal essay.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: What a great article! Thanks for sharing it. Like you, my default is "aggressive editor", but I'd like to think that part of that aggression lies in getting the best of my writers and making sure they're using their skills to the best of their abilities. To that end, so much of it has to do with setting expectations at the beginning, in my experience. Being very honest w/ a new writer that I'm tough on words and passionate about a good story, so I come off as intense, but I promise I'm working for their good and the good of the piece. And building trust both ways. I ask them to trust me, and I have to trust them. So if I read just a real, "WTF" sentence or piece, I have to trust the writer had a good idea in mind, or there's a seed of something there, I just have to talk with them about it to get to the right words. And, worst case scenario, if a writer just isn't working out (very rare this has happened) being honest about that, too. Try and help them down a path or towards a different publication that's a better fit.

text:
<@U012UL77GUT> Setting expectations, always important :slightly_smiling_face: More recently I've found myself "This is going to be challenging and is not an insignificant time commitment" rather than "I'll help you and we can turn this around by next week!"

Good writing is hard! And I want people to understand that it's an investment they're making in their professional development. It's worth the effort, but it's certainly not easy.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: Funny, I think about this in “levels” rather than your much better and more memorable head/spine <https://twitter.com/SeanBlanda/status/1149351138036203520>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/SeanBlanda|@SeanBlanda>: Categories of edits, in order:
Topic - The pitch, the urgency of the topic, relevancy to audience
Outline - Does writer have something to say with evidence / examples / insights?
Cohesion - Do arguments hang together? 
Framing - headline, intro, distro plans
Line - grammar, etc
attachments.text:
Categories of edits, in order:
Topic - The pitch, the urgency of the topic, relevancy to audience
Outline - Does writer have something to say with evidence / examples / insights?
Cohesion - Do arguments hang together? 
Framing - headline, intro, distro plans
Line - grammar, etc

text:
I'm glad it resonates! I just started talking about spines with a few people I'm coaching and it seems to resonate really well. I think "outline" conjures shitty outlines we were told to make for high school essays.

For me, spine captures the movement or journey you're trying to take people on.

text: Love the piece. Something you didn't address is how long to let the editing process stretch out. Right now, I'm working with a "half-time" writer who does customer support the other half of the time. This means that edits and rewrites can stretch on for days, making it hard to maintain momentum. On the other hand, some pieces are better if you give them a few days or even weeks of breathing room. I'm curious if others have hard and fast rules for how long their editing process should take.

elements.text: Love the piece. Something you didn't address is how long to let the editing process stretch out. oh yeah...that's a good one that depends so much on who the writer is:
-- a CM on my team, yep, you can control that
-- someone from another team for whom writing isn't a core part of their job :shrug:
-- a customer (this is one I'm working on now) it's just 100% about being a friendly partner
